title: 109_s3559
content: The Act titled "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a section on fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It outlines penalties for falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to benefits authorized in connection with disaster declarations or emergency procurement. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes penalties for fraud related to disaster benefits, including fines and imprisonment for up to 30 years for individuals involved in fraudulent activities connected to emergency declarations or procurement of property or services with the United States. The term "benefit" in this context refers to any valuable item or service related to interstate or foreign commerce, mail transportation, or government records. The term "benefit" in the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" refers to any valuable item or service provided by the United States, State, or local government. SEC. 3 and SEC. 4 of the Act increase criminal penalties for wire, radio, and television fraud, as well as mail fraud, in connection with benefits related to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. The term "benefit" refers to any valuable item or service provided by the government. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must submit an explanation to Congress and make policy recommendations to combat these offenses. The Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of these crimes. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of fraud or theft offenses related to major disasters or emergencies. They must make necessary changes to the guidelines to meet sentencing purposes and deadlines for action. The Commission must promptly establish guidelines or amendments within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, following the procedures of the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987.
